title: George Boyle, 6th Earl of Glasgow
text:
George Frederick Boyle, 6th Earl of Glasgow (9 October 1825 – 23 April 1890) was a Scottish nobleman.
He was the son of <a href="George%20Boyle%2C%204th%20Earl%20of%20Glasgow">George Boyle, 4th Earl of Glasgow</a> and Julia Sinclair, daughter of <a href="Sir%20John%20Sinclair%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir John Sinclair, 1st Baronet</a>.
In February 1847, Boyle traveled with <a href="Frederick%20Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Dufferin%20and%20Ava">Frederick Hamilton-Temple-Blackwood, 1st Marquess of Dufferin and Ava</a> to <a href="Skibbereen">Skibbereen</a> in <a href="County%20Cork">County Cork</a> to try and aid victims of the <a href="Irish%20Famine">Irish Famine</a>. Lord Dufferin left a memoir of their journey entitled "<a href="Narrative%20of%20a%20Journey%20from%20Oxford%20to%20Skibbereen%20during%20the%20Year%20of%20the%20Irish%20Famine">Narrative of a Journey from Oxford to Skibbereen during the Year of the Irish Famine</a>" published in 1847 (27 pages).
He married Hon. Montague Abercromby (1835–1931), daughter of <a href="George%20Abercromby%2C%203rd%20Baron%20Abercromby">George Abercromby, 3rd Baron Abercromby</a> and Louisa Penuel Forbes, on 29 April 1856. They had two daughters
He was elected at a <a href="1865%20Buteshire%20by-election">by-election in February 1865</a> as the <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for <a href="Buteshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Buteshire</a>, but held the seat only until the <a href="1865%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">general election in July 1865</a>.
He succeeded to his half brother's titles on 11 March 1869.
He held the offices of <a href="deputy%20lieutenant">deputy lieutenant</a> of <a href="Fife">Fife</a> and <a href="Renfrewshire">Renfrewshire</a>. He held the office of <a href="Lord%20Clerk%20Register">Lord Clerk Register</a> of Scotland from 1879 until his death.
He died at age 64, without male issue. On his death, the UK barony of <a href="Baron%20Ross">Ross of Hawkhead</a> became extinct.
Religion.
Boyle was an <a href="Scottish%20Episcopal%20Church">Episcopalian</a> and was a long time associate of Bishop <a href="Alexander%20Penrose%20Forbes">Alexander Penrose Forbes</a> and a supporter of his views. Correspondence between the two men is held by the <a href="University%20of%20Dundee">University of Dundee</a>'s archives. In 1848 the Boyle founded a choir school attached to the Church of St. Andrews, <a href="Millport%2C%20Cumbrae">Millport</a>. He followed this up in 1849 by founding and endowing the Episcopal College and <a href="Cathedral%20of%20The%20Isles">Collegiate Church of the Holy Spirit</a>, <a href="Cumbrae">Cumbrae</a>. The college was completed in 1851 to plans by William Butterfield and was later affiliated to the <a href="University%20of%20Durham">University of Durham</a> as Cumbrae Theological College. While the Collegiate Church was elevated to the status of Cathedral of Argyll and the Isles in 1879, the college ultimately closed in 1888.
